definition: Describes a plant that sheds its leaves annually, which is typical of some but not all plant species in temperate zones.
A plant that lives for more than two years, typically regenerating each growing season.
The area along a shoreline that is covered by water at high tide and exposed during low tide.
To pass waste materials from the body; in the context of the ecosystem, it refers to the process by which organisms eliminate waste that can still be nutrient-rich.
Marine organisms that live below the low tide mark, continuously submerged underwater.

The underlying surface or medium that provides the foundation for organisms; in this context, it refers to sand, silt, gravel, or cobble.
The concentration of salt in water, significant for plants like Spartina that grow in saline environments.
Chemical compounds containing sulfur that are typically found in marsh sediments and can be toxic to most plants.

A natural or artificial feature that catches and holds sediment, helping to stabilize an area by accumulating soil.
Water that has more salinity than fresh water, but not as much as seawater, often found in estuaries.
The process by which soil and rock are removed from the Earth's surface by natural processes such as wind or water flow.

The process of creating new land from ocean, riverbeds, or lake beds.
